definition: (physical) An area; somewhere within an area.
One's calling in life; a person's occupation; one's profession.
(heading) Employment.
A place or location.
A long dowel or plank protruding from the ground; a fencepost; a lightpost.
(Singlish) Used to contradict an underlying assumption held by the interlocutor.
A specific commercial enterprise or establishment.
An activity or task with which one occupies oneself; usually specifically the productive activity, service, trade, or craft for which one is regularly paid; a job.
Offspring.
A right to sell something at a predetermined price.
A legally or socially binding conceptual contract of entitlement to wealth, void of intrinsic value, payable for all debts and taxes, and regulated in supply.
A task.
A place or location.
A difficulty that has to be resolved or dealt with.
Payment for the temporary use of something.
A piece of work done as part of one’s duties.
That which one is morally or legally obligated to do.
The work or occupation for which one is used, and often paid
A summary or synopsis.
A task.
A declaration of belief, faith or one's opinion, whether genuine or pretended.
A person who performs labor for a living, especially manual labor.
One who enters into, or offers for, any service of his/her own free will, especially when done without pay.
An individual who provides labor to a company or another person.
To pay (a debt, fine etc.).
The act of assigning; the allocation of a job or a set of tasks.
A person, firm or other entity which pays for or hires the services of another person.
A period of time spent doing or being something; a spell.
Payment for the temporary use of something.
Having or showing skill; skillful.
A fixed amount of money paid to a worker, usually calculated on a monthly or annual basis, not hourly, as wages. Implies a degree of professionalism and/or autonomy.
The state of being an employee; employment.
(often in plural) An amount of money paid to a worker for a specified quantity of work, usually calculated on an hourly basis and expressed in an amount of money per hour.
Of or relating to a manager or management; involving management-like duties.
To work as a freelance.
A person, firm or other entity which pays for or hires the services of another person.
An unoccupied position or job.
To obtain the services of in return for fixed payment.
The place where someone works.
The act of binding oneself by a social, legal, or moral tie to someone.
A job taken by a student in order to learn a profession or trade.
To work as a waitress.
An inclination to undertake a certain kind of work, especially a religious career; often in response to a perceived summons; a calling.
To think, meditate or reflect on a subject; to consider, to deliberate or cogitate.
The amount of work assigned to a particular worker, normally in a specified time period

The function of compiling and providing financial information primarily by reports referred to as financial statements, including bookkeeping, systems design, analysis and interpretation of accounting information.
One who uses body strength instead of intellectual power to earn a wage, usually hourly.
A summary or synopsis.
A playful leap or jump.
The value that one ought to work hard at one's job or duties.
A job taken by a student in order to learn a profession or trade.
A servant, especially a domestic servant.
Pertaining to a secretary.
To hire again.
The condition of, or the time served by, an apprentice.
A task, especially a difficult, unpleasant, or routine one.
Not filled, especially occupational positions.
Involving a full amount of time spent on some activity, especially a job.
A portion of a contracted project that is contracted out in turn.
(of a task) not appreciated or rewarded
To hire again.
Having too many qualifications to be deemed appropriate for a (usually unskilled) job.
A group, collection, category or set sharing characteristics or attributes.

The state of organisms preceding their death, characterized by biological processes such as metabolism and reproduction and distinguishing them from inanimate objects; the state of being alive and living.
A team; a group of people who work together professionally.
A character or part played by a performer or actor.
(collective) A group of fish or a group of marine mammals such as porpoises, dolphins, or whales.
Money one earns by working or by capitalising on the work of others.
The tendency to work persistently. Diligence.
The process of imparting knowledge, skill and judgment.
An activity that one enjoys doing in one's spare time.
A land area free of woodland, cities, and towns; open country.
Distasteful tasks.
A person who is interned, forcibly or voluntarily.
Money given in return for work; salary or wages.
A corporate group; a group of colleagues.
A group of people who are closely related to one another (by blood, marriage or adoption); kin; for example, a set of parents and their children; an immediate family.

A stage of proficiency or qualification in a course of study, now especially an award bestowed by a university or, in some countries, a college, as a certification of academic achievement. (In the United States, can include secondary schools.)
To keep within a structure or container.
A person who oversees and directs the work of others; a supervisor.
Related to finances.
An official face-to-face meeting of monarchs or other important figures.
An advancement in rank or position.
With a comparative or with more and a verb phrase, establishes a correlation with one or more other such comparatives.
Capacity to do something well; technique, ability. Skills are usually acquired or learned, as opposed to abilities, which are often thought of as innate.
A planned endeavor, usually with a specific goal and accomplished in several steps or stages.
A style of living that reflects the attitudes and values of a person or group.
A bounding straight edge of a two-dimensional shape.
A dwelling.
